page.title: 09THE CHILDREN OF LESWALT
page.content: The child of 1985 is largerly the product of the mass media and it becomes ever more difficult to decide nationality or, often, sex at a glance. Fortunately, the countryside of parent or grandparent has still considerable influence. Field, tree and stream, tree-house, tadpole and trout play a large part in the life of the village child. Street games survive. Hop-scotch and skipping, tag and hide-and-seek, marbles, roller skates and biycles, football, netball and hockey in season. Local accent in speech is still very evident, the Scot's tongue with the back-ward 'L' of the Irish, and odd words, as 'ocht' - something or anything, peculiar to the area. In dress we are universal. The full school uniform survives but outside school it is blue jeans and T-shirt.
